title: Baxter May Amend Five Years of Results After Finding Accounting Error
text:
By Micah Maidenberg

Baxter International Inc. said it might need to restate at least five years of results as it has discovered misstatements related to foreign-exchange transactions over the period.

The health-products company said Thursday that it had opened an investigation into the transactions, which it said occurred between different parts of Baxter and were undertaken to generate foreign-exchange gains or losses.

Shares fell 7% in premarket trading.

The intra-company transactions used an exchange-rate method that didn't comply with generally accepted accounting principles, Baxter said. The misstatements affect the net foreign-exchange gains each year from 2014 to last year, as well as the first half of this year, the company said.

Baxter, of Deerfield, Ill., warned that its investigation into the matter isn't limited to this time span and said any changes to its previously reported foreign-exchange gains and losses might change its nonoperating-income results.

Baxter has hired outside attorneys and consultants related to the matter. The investigation is in its early stages, the company said.

When the investigation is complete, Baxter expects to either amend previous financial statements that it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to correct for errors, or to include in reports for future periods restated results allowing for comparability.

"The company is working diligently and expeditiously to address the nonoperating related accounting issue," Chief Executive José Almeida said.
